Different infrastructures handle settlement differently, reflecting trade-offs between
: Payments settled individually, in real-time, with finality

Pan-European RTGS system operated by the Eurosystem

Backbone of European financial stability infrastructure
: Batch-processing system with net settlement (end-of-day or periodic)
Cost-efficient, less liquidity needed compared to RTGS
: Nacha ACH (US), SEPA Credit Transfer/Direct Debit (EU)
: low-value, high-volume payments (salaries, utility bills, e-commerce)
: slower than RTGS; settlement not instantaneous
ACH Example: SEPA (Single Euro Payments Area)
with same rules and costs across participating countries. Launched 2008, fully implemented by 2014.
(euro-denominated payments only): 36 countries: EU + EFTA (Iceland, Norway, Liechtenstein, Switzerland) + Monaco, San Marino, Andorra, Vatican
: Standardized euro transfers, usually settled next day (D+1)
